Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Percutaneous Laser Ablation for Invasive Ductal Breast Carcinoma

Participants.evidence: Women aged 18-80 with a single focus of IDC ≤20 mm were enrolled across nine sites.

Intervention.evidence: Participants underwent PLA followed by a 28-day post-ablation MRI and surgical resection.

Objective.evidence: This multicenter, open-label, phase 2 trial aimed to evaluate the efficacy of percutaneous laser ablation (PLA) in treating invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) and to compare post-ablation MRI with surgical pathology.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was complete tumor ablation, assessed by pathology.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation and blinding were not applicable.

Blinding.evidence: Randomisation and blinding were not applicable.

Number_Randomised.evidence: From June 2012 to May 2015, 61 patients were treated.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Complete tumor ablation was confirmed in 51 (84%) patients.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Complete tumor ablation was confirmed in 51 (84%) patients. MRI-pathology correlation was evaluable in 60 patients, with an MRI negative predictive value of 92.2% (95% CI, 71.9–91.9%).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild to moderate, with no serious events reported.
